q: Who was the last Governor-General and the first Viceroy of India?
desc: Lord Canning was the last Governor-General and became the first Viceroy of India after the Act of 1858.

q: Which policy was withdrawn by Lord Canning?
desc: Lord Canning officially withdrew the Doctrine of Lapse.

q: Who was the Viceroy during the Revolt of 1857?
desc: The Revolt of 1857, also called the First War of Independence, took place during Lord Canning's tenure.

q: Which act ended the rule of the East India Company?
desc: The Government of India Act 1858 transferred rule from the East India Company to the British Crown.

q: Which three universities were established in 1857?
desc: The Universities of Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras were established in 1857 under Lord Canning.

q: When was the Indian Penal Code passed?
desc: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) was passed in 1860 during Lord Canning's tenure.

q: Which movement took place during Lord Elgin’s tenure?
desc: The Wahabi Movement was active during Lord Elgin’s tenure.

q: Who established the High Courts in Bombay, Madras, and Calcutta?
desc: The High Courts at Bombay, Madras, and Calcutta were established in 1865 during Lord Lawrence’s rule.

q: Under whose viceroyalty was telegraphic communication established with Europe?
desc: Lord Lawrence established telegraphic communication between India and Europe.

q: Who created the Indian Forest Department?
desc: Lord Lawrence established the Indian Forest Department to regulate forest resources.

q: When was the first Indian census held?
desc: The first census in Indian history was held in 1871 under Lord Mayo.

q: Who organized the Statistical Survey of India?
desc: Lord Mayo initiated the Statistical Survey of India.

q: Which viceroy started financial decentralization in India?
desc: Lord Mayo began financial decentralization by delegating financial authority to provinces.

q: Which department was established by Lord Mayo for economic affairs?
desc: Lord Mayo established the Department of Agriculture and Commerce.

q: Where was Mayo College established?
desc: Mayo College for Indian princes was established in Ajmer under Lord Mayo.

q: Which college for Indian princes was set up in Kathiawar?
desc: Rajkot College at Kathiawar was established by Lord Mayo.

q: Who was the only Viceroy of India to be murdered while in office?
desc: Lord Mayo was assassinated by a Pathan convict in the Andaman Islands in 1872.

q: Which rebellion occurred in Punjab during Lord Northbrooke’s tenure?
desc: The Kuka Rebellion took place in Punjab during the time of Lord Northbrooke.

q: Which viceroy ruled during the famine in Bihar?
desc: A severe famine hit Bihar during the tenure of Lord Northbrooke.

q: Who is referred to as the ‘Viceroy of Reverse Character’?
desc: Lord Lytton earned the nickname ‘Viceroy of Reverse Character’ for his controversial policies.

q: Which act gave Queen Victoria the title ‘Empress of India’?
desc: The Royal Titles Act of 1876 declared Queen Victoria the Empress of India.

q: In which event was Queen Victoria proclaimed Empress of India?
desc: Queen Victoria’s title as Empress of India was proclaimed during the Delhi Durbar in 1877.

q: Which act, also known as the ‘Gagging Act’, was passed in 1878?
desc: The Vernacular Press Act of 1878 restricted the freedom of Indian language newspapers.

q: What did the Arms Act of 1878 mandate?
desc: The Arms Act required Indians to obtain licenses to carry arms, unlike Europeans.

q: During which viceroy's rule was the Delhi Durbar of 1877 held?
desc: The Delhi Durbar of 1877, where Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress, was held under Lord Lytton.

q: Which Viceroy passed both the Vernacular Press Act and Arms Act?
desc: Both the Vernacular Press Act and Arms Act were passed in 1878 during Lord Lytton's rule.

q: Which Viceroy introduced measures to promote education for Indian princes?
desc: Lord Mayo established institutions like Mayo College and Rajkot College for educating Indian princes.

q: Which Viceroy started India's first comprehensive statistical survey?
desc: Lord Mayo launched the first systematic Statistical Survey of India.

q: In which year did Lord Mayo get assassinated?
desc: Lord Mayo was assassinated in the Andaman Islands in 1872.

q: Who is known as the founding father of local self-governance in India?
desc: Lord Ripon introduced Local Self-Government in 1882 and is considered its founding father in India.

q: Which Factory Act prohibited child labour under age 7?
desc: The Factory Act of 1881, passed under Lord Ripon, prohibited child labour under the age of 7.

q: In which year was local self-government introduced in India?
desc: Lord Ripon introduced local self-government in 1882, laying the foundation for decentralised administration.

q: Which act was repealed by Lord Ripon in 1882?
desc: The Vernacular Press Act, which restricted press freedom, was repealed by Lord Ripon in 1882.

q: What was the main objective of the Hunter Commission appointed in 1882?
desc: The Hunter Commission was appointed in 1882 to improve primary and secondary education in India.

q: What did the Ilbert Bill of 1883 propose?
desc: The Ilbert Bill proposed allowing Indian judges to try European offenders, sparking widespread controversy.

q: During whose tenure was the Indian National Congress founded?
desc: The Indian National Congress was founded in 1885 during Lord Dufferin’s viceroyalty.

q: Which war took place during Lord Dufferin’s tenure?
desc: The Third Burmese War (1885–86) occurred during Lord Dufferin's time, resulting in British annexation of Burma.

q: Which Factory Act granted weekly holidays and working hour regulations for women and children?
desc: The Factory Act of 1891, passed under Lord Lansdowne, regulated working hours and granted weekly holidays.

q: Under which viceroy was the Indian Civil Services divided into three categories?
desc: Lord Lansdowne reorganized civil services into Imperial, Provincial, and Subordinate Services.

q: Which act passed in 1892 gave Indians representation in legislative councils?
desc: The Indian Councils Act of 1892 allowed limited Indian representation in legislative councils.

q: What was the Durand Line established in 1893?
desc: The Durand Line, demarcated by the Durand Commission in 1893, marked the boundary between British India and Afghanistan.

q: Which two modern countries does the Durand Line now separate?
desc: The Durand Line today forms the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

q: Which viceroy faced the great famine of 1896–1897?
desc: The great famine of 1896–97 occurred under the viceroyalty of Lord Elgin II.

q: Which commission was set up in response to the famine of 1896–1897?
desc: The Lyall Commission was established to investigate causes of the 1896–97 famine.

q: Which viceroy initiated reforms in Indian universities?
desc: Lord Curzon appointed the Raleigh Commission in 1902, leading to the Indian Universities Act of 1904.

q: Who passed the Indian Universities Act of 1904?
desc: The Indian Universities Act of 1904, passed under Lord Curzon, aimed to regulate and improve university education.

q: Which act aimed at preserving ancient monuments in India?
desc: Lord Curzon passed the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act in 1904, laying the foundation for the Archaeological Survey of India.

q: What institution was founded at Pusa in Delhi under Lord Curzon?
desc: The Agricultural Research Institute at Pusa was established by Lord Curzon for agricultural advancement.

q: Which major event in Bengal's history occurred in 1905?
desc: Lord Curzon partitioned Bengal in 1905, which triggered massive protests and the Swadeshi Movement.

q: What was the main aim of the Raleigh Commission of 1902?
desc: The Raleigh Commission was set up to suggest reforms for Indian universities, leading to the 1904 Act.

q: Which viceroy’s reforms led to the foundation of the Archaeological Survey of India?
desc: Lord Curzon’s Ancient Monuments Preservation Act led to the establishment of the Archaeological Survey of India.

q: Which viceroy's rule saw the division of civil services into different branches?
desc: Lord Lansdowne divided civil services into Imperial, Provincial, and Subordinate categories.

q: Who presided over India during the Third Burmese War?
desc: The Third Burmese War (1885–86) occurred under the viceroyalty of Lord Dufferin.

q: Which viceroy is associated with the Ilbert Bill controversy?
desc: The Ilbert Bill, which caused significant opposition from Europeans, was introduced under Lord Ripon.

q: Who repealed the repressive Vernacular Press Act?
desc: Lord Ripon repealed the Vernacular Press Act in 1882, restoring press freedom for Indian-language newspapers.

q: During whose tenure was the Indian National Congress formed?
desc: The Indian National Congress was formed in 1885 while Lord Dufferin was Viceroy.

q: Which viceroy is associated with both famine and tribal uprisings?
desc: Lord Elgin II witnessed both the great famine and southern tribal uprisings during his rule.

q: Who was the Viceroy of India during the foundation of the Muslim League?
desc: The All-India Muslim League was founded in 1906 during the tenure of Lord Minto.

q: In which year did the Swadeshi Movement start?
desc: The Swadeshi Movement began in 1905 as a reaction to the partition of Bengal.

q: Which Congress session led to a split between moderates and extremists?
desc: The Surat Session of Congress in 1907 witnessed a split between moderates and extremists.

q: Which reform is associated with Lord Minto?
desc: The Morley-Minto Reforms of 1909 expanded the legislative councils and introduced separate electorates for Muslims.

q: Who was the Viceroy when the capital of India was shifted from Calcutta to Delhi?
desc: In 1911, under Lord Hardinge, the capital was shifted from Calcutta to Delhi.

q: Which event led to the cancellation of the Partition of Bengal?
desc: The Delhi Durbar of 1911 marked the annulment of the 1905 Partition of Bengal.

q: Who founded the Hindu Mahasabha in 1915?
desc: The Hindu Mahasabha was founded in 1915 by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya.

q: Which ashram did Gandhi establish in 1916?
desc: Gandhi established the Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad in 1916.

q: Which was Gandhi's first Satyagraha in India?
desc: Champaran Satyagraha in 1917 was Gandhi’s first major civil disobedience in India.

q: Which act was passed in March 1919 that caused widespread anger in India?
desc: The Rowlatt Act allowed detention without trial and led to nationwide protests.

q: When did the Jallianwala Bagh massacre take place?
desc: The Jallianwala Bagh massacre happened on 13th April 1919 in Amritsar.

q: Which movement began as a protest against British support to the disintegration of the Ottoman Empire?
desc: The Khilafat Movement (1919–20) protested against British actions in the Ottoman Empire.

q: Who was the Viceroy during the Non-Cooperation Movement?
desc: Lord Chelmsford was Viceroy when the Non-Cooperation Movement started in 1920.

q: Where was the Women’s University founded in 1916?
desc: India's first Women’s University was founded in Poona in 1916.

q: Which Viceroy repealed the Rowlatt Act?
desc: The Rowlatt Act was repealed during Lord Reading's tenure (1921–26).

q: What major incident in 1922 led Gandhi to call off the Non-Cooperation Movement?
desc: The Chauri-Chaura incident involved violence that led Gandhi to suspend the Non-Cooperation Movement.

q: Which organization was founded in 1925?
desc: RSS was founded in 1925 as a right-wing Hindu nationalist organization.

q: Which rebellion occurred in 1921 in Kerala involving Muslim peasants?
desc: The Moplah Rebellion in 1921 involved Muslim tenants rising against landlords in Kerala.

q: When did the Kakori Train Robbery take place?
desc: The Kakori Train Robbery was conducted by revolutionaries on 1st August 1925.

q: Which Viceroy faced the Communal Riots of 1923-25?
desc: Communal riots during 1923–25 occurred under Lord Reading's tenure.

q: Who was the Viceroy when the Simon Commission came to India?
desc: The Simon Commission arrived in 1927 during Lord Irwin’s rule.

q: What significant event did Gandhi start on 12th March 1930?
desc: The Dandi March began on 12th March 1930 as part of the Civil Disobedience Movement.

q: What movement was launched following the Dandi March?
desc: The Civil Disobedience Movement was launched in 1930 following the Salt March.

q: Where was the First Round Table Conference held?
desc: The First Round Table Conference was held in London in 1930.

q: What was the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
pool: Gandhi’s participation in Round Table Conference
answer: Gandhi’s participation in Round Table Conference
desc: The Gandhi-Irwin Pact allowed Gandhi to attend the Second Round Table Conference.

q: In which session of Congress was the Poorna Swaraj Declaration made?
desc: In the Lahore Session of 1929, Congress declared Poorna Swaraj (complete independence) as its goal.

q: Who was the Viceroy during the Dandi March?
desc: The Dandi March occurred under the rule of Lord Irwin in 1930.

q: Which year saw the formation of the Swaraj Party?
desc: The Swaraj Party was formed in 1923 by Motilal Nehru and C.R. Das.

q: Who returned to India in 1915 and became a key figure in the independence movement?
desc: Mahatma Gandhi returned to India from South Africa in 1915.

q: During whose tenure did the Second Round Table Conference take place?
desc: The Second Round Table Conference was held in 1931 during Lord Willingdon's tenure.

q: When was the Government of India Act passed?
desc: The Government of India Act was passed in 1935, introducing provincial autonomy and federal structure.

q: What was the main issue with the Communal Award of 1932?
desc: The Communal Award of 1932 proposed separate electorates for Dalits, which Gandhi opposed through a fast.

q: Who protested against the Communal Award by going on an epic fast?
desc: Gandhi went on a fast to oppose separate electorates for Dalits under the Communal Award.

q: Which Viceroy oversaw the Third Round Table Conference?
desc: The Third Round Table Conference took place in 1932 under Lord Willingdon's rule.

q: Which Viceroy witnessed the resignation of Congress Ministries?
desc: Congress Ministries resigned in 1939 during Lord Linlithgow's tenure as Viceroy.

q: What day did the Muslim League celebrate after Congress ministries resigned?
desc: The Muslim League celebrated Congress resignations in 1939 as Deliverance Day.

q: What was the Lahore Resolution of 1940?
desc: The Lahore Resolution passed in 1940 called for a separate nation for Muslims—later Pakistan.

q: Who proposed the Two-Nation Theory?
desc: Jinnah put forward the Two-Nation Theory during the Lahore Session of 1940.

q: Which global event began during Lord Linlithgow's tenure?
desc: World War II began in 1939 during the viceroyalty of Lord Linlithgow.

q: Which mission was sent by the British to negotiate with Indian leaders in 1942?
desc: The Cripps Mission was sent in 1942 to negotiate terms with Indian leaders during WWII.

q: When was the Quit India Movement launched?
desc: The Quit India Movement was launched by the INC on 8th August 1942.

q: Who was the Viceroy when the Quit India Movement started?
desc: Lord Linlithgow was the Viceroy when the Quit India Movement began in 1942.

q: Which mission proposed a three-tier federal structure in 1946?
desc: The Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946 proposed a three-tier federal structure for India.

q: Which Viceroy arranged the Shimla Conference in 1945?
desc: Lord Wavell arranged the Shimla Conference in 1945, which ended in failure.

q: What was the purpose of the Shimla Conference?
desc: The Shimla Conference attempted to bring the Congress and the Muslim League to an agreement.

q: When was the first meeting of the Constituent Assembly held?
desc: The first meeting of the Constituent Assembly was held on 9th December 1946.

q: Under whom was the interim government formed in 1946?
desc: Jawaharlal Nehru headed the interim government formed in 1946.

q: Who was the last Viceroy of British India?
desc: Lord Mountbatten was the last British Viceroy and the first Governor-General of free India.

q: What was the Mountbatten Plan also known as?
desc: The Mountbatten Plan for the partition of India was announced on 3rd June 1947.

q: Who succeeded Lord Mountbatten as the Governor-General of India?
desc: C. Rajagopalachari was the first and last Indian Governor-General after Mountbatten.

q: When was the Indian Independence Act passed by the British Parliament?
desc: The Indian Independence Act was passed on 4th July 1947 by the British Parliament.

q: When did India become independent?
desc: India became independent on 15th August 1947 following the Indian Independence Act.

q: Who was the first Governor-General of independent India?
desc: Lord Mountbatten served as the first Governor-General of free India.

q: Which Viceroy was responsible for overseeing India’s transition to independence?
desc: Lord Mountbatten managed the process of partition and India’s independence in 1947.

q: What did the Cabinet Mission aim to achieve?
desc: The Cabinet Mission sought to set up a Constitution-making body and a federal government.

q: Which Viceroy convened the Constituent Assembly?
desc: Lord Wavell oversaw the convening of the Constituent Assembly and the interim government.

q: When was the Shimla Conference held?
desc: The Shimla Conference was held on 25th June 1945 to negotiate terms between INC and the Muslim League.

q: What was the main outcome of the Shimla Conference?
desc: The Shimla Conference failed due to disagreements between Congress and the Muslim League.
